scenario_purpose: The European Interoperability Framework(EIF) provides guidance to public administrations on how to improve governance of their interoperability activities, establish cross-organisational relationships, streamline processes supporting end-to-end digital services, and ensure that existing and new legislation do not compromise interoperability efforts.This CAMSS Scenario allows to assess the compliance of interoperability specifications with the EIF. The objective of the obtained assessment is to determine the suitability of the assessed interoperability specification for the delivery of interoperable European public services.
criterion_description: The standard or specification has been included in a national catalogue from a Member State whose NIF is fully aligned with at least 4 out of 5 sections of the EIF according to NIFO factsheets.
statement:
TLS 1.2 is included in two national catalogues, which belong to Member States complying with at least 4 out of 5 sections of the EIF according to the NIFO factsheets.

See:                                                                                                                                               https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/collection/common-assessment-method-standards-and-specifications-camss/camss-list-standards

scenario_purpose: The European Interoperability Framework(EIF) provides guidance to public administrations on how to improve governance of their interoperability activities, establish cross-organisational relationships, streamline processes supporting end-to-end digital services, and ensure that existing and new legislation do not compromise interoperability efforts.This CAMSS Scenario allows to assess the compliance of interoperability specifications with the EIF. The objective of the obtained assessment is to determine the suitability of the assessed interoperability specification for the delivery of interoperable European public services.
criterion_description: The standard or specification facilitates the publication of public data as open data.
statement: The purpose of TLS 1.2 is not related to the publication of public data as open data to European public services. Therefore this criterion is considered not applicable specification.

scenario_purpose: The European Interoperability Framework(EIF) provides guidance to public administrations on how to improve governance of their interoperability activities, establish cross-organisational relationships, streamline processes supporting end-to-end digital services, and ensure that existing and new legislation do not compromise interoperability efforts.This CAMSS Scenario allows to assess the compliance of interoperability specifications with the EIF. criterion_description: All stakeholders have the opportunity to contribute to the development of the specificationÂ
statement:
IETF has a formal review and approval so that all the relevant stakeholders can formally appeal or raise objections to the development and approval of specifications.

Each distinct version of an Internet standards-related specification is published as part of the "Request for Comments" (RFC) document series. This archival series is the official publication channel for Internet standards documents and other publications.

During the development of a specification, draft versions of the document are made available for informal review and comment by placing them in the IETF's "Internet-Drafts" directory, which is replicated on a number of Internet hosts. This makes an evolving working document readily available to a wide audience, facilitating the process of review and revision.

See:
https://tools.ietf.org/id/draft-gutmann-tls-lts-10.html

criterion_description: A public review is part of the decision-making process.

statement:
TLS 1.2 is publicly available for study and use at no cost on the IETF webpage. 

See:
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5246

criterion_description: The standard or specification is licensed on a (F)RAND basis
statement:
Like all the IETF standards, TLS 1.2 is  a free and open technical specification, built on IETF standards and licenses from the Open Web Foundation. FTP is licensed on a F(RAND) basis.

See:
https://tools.ietf.org/id/draft-gutmann-tls-lts-10.html

criterion_description: The standard or specification is licensed on a royalty-free basis
statement:
Like all the IETF standards, TLS 1.2 is  a free and open technical specification, built on IETF standards and licenses from the Open Web Foundation. TLS 1.2 is therefore licensed on a royalty-free basis.

See:
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3668

scenario_purpose: The European Interoperability Framework(EIF) provides guidance to public administrations on how to improve governance of their interoperability activities, establish cross-organisational relationships, streamline processes supporting end-to-end digital services, and ensure that existing and new legislation do not compromise interoperability efforts.This CAMSS Scenario allows to assess the compliance of interoperability specifications with the EIF. criterion_description: The standard or specification is sufficiently mature and has sufficient market acceptance for its use in the development of products and services.
statement: TSL 1.2 has been widely for cryptographic protocol that providing end-to-end security of data sent between applications over the Internet. However TSL 1.3 was created in 2018 which improved many characteristics of the  former, consequently it can be said that it is the 1.3 version that is used for the development of products and services.

scenario_purpose: The European Interoperability Framework(EIF) provides guidance to public administrations on how to improve governance of their interoperability activities, establish cross-organisational relationships, streamline processes supporting end-to-end digital services, and ensure that existing and new legislation do not compromise interoperability efforts.This CAMSS Scenario allows to assess the compliance of interoperability specifications with the EIF. The objective of the obtained assessment is to determine the suitability of the assessed interoperability specification for the delivery of interoperable European public services.
criterion_description: The standard or specification fosters the creation of innovative solutions.
statement: At the time of elaborating this assessment, TLS 1.2 does not foster the creation of innovative solutions. In 2018 the creation of TLS 1.3 updated and improved the older version. So the focus of creating innovative solution is focused on the  latter.

scenario_purpose: The European Interoperability Framework(EIF) provides guidance to public administrations on how to improve governance of their interoperability activities, establish cross-organisational relationships, streamline processes supporting end-to-end digital services, and ensure that existing and new legislation do not compromise interoperability efforts.This CAMSS Scenario allows to assess the compliance of interoperability specifications with the EIF. statement:
TLS 1.2 is developed and maintained by IETF, a widely recognised open international community developing standards to enhance the internet. 
See: 
https://www.ietf.org/
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5246

statement: The purpose of TLS 1.2 is not related to fostering visibility and comprehensibility of administrative rules, processes, data, services and decision-making of a public administration. . Therefore this criterion is considered not applicable specification.

statement: The purpose of TLS 1.2 is not related to the availability of interfaces. Therefore this criterion is considered not applicable specification.

criterion_description: The standard or specification is reusable beyond the domain for which it was originally developed.Â
statement: As a business domain agnostic specification, TLS 1.2, contributes with the security during the exchange of documents addressing any domain.

statement:
The TLS 1.2 is published as a reusable solution in Joinup, the collaborative platform for Reusable IT Solutions funded by the European Commission. 

See: 
https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/solution/tls-rfc-5246-transport-layer-security-protocol

criterion_description: The standard or specification is independent from any specific technology and/or platform.
statement: TLS 1.2 is independent of any specification and can be implemented without dependencies with technologies or platforms. Moreover, IETF is a neutral-vendor Standard Developing Organisation that has developed the technical specification independently of any vendor product.

criterion_description: The standard or specification is proportionate to the needs of its users (citizens, businesses or administrations).
statement: The adoption of TLS 1.2 does not affect the system scalability. However, the new 1.3 version has improved security. Despite having this situation the interoperability is not affected due to its fluid interconectness.

statement: The purpose of TLS 1.2 is to provide communication security regarding privacy and data integrity. It can be concluded that TLS 1.2 collaborates in a way to proper data portability.

statement: By securing the communication through computer networks it allows the data exchange and information reuse between public administrations.

statement: The purpose of TLS 1.2 is not related to  e-accessibility. Therefore this criterion is considered not applicable to this specification.

statement:
TLS 1.2 is a protocol cryptographic protocol that provides end-to-end security of data sent between applications over the Internet.

See: 
https://www.internetsociety.org/deploy360/tls/basics/

criterion_description: The adoption of the standard or specification reduces the administrative burden.
statement: By securing data exchange through computer networks, TLS 1.2 allows the information exchange between administrations and its stakeholders. Thus, the adoption of TLS 1.2 avoids the analogical data exchange reducing the administrative burden.

statement: The purpose of TLS 1.2 is not related to long term preservation of electronic records. Therefore this criterion is considered not applicable to this specification

criterion_description: There are already existing studies or documentation assessing the standard or specification in terms of effectiveness and efficiency.
statement:
There are several studies assessing the strengths, weaknesses, effectiveness, and efficiency of TLS which include several references to the version that is being assessed. Moreover, the studies compare the performance form the different versions laying emphasis on strengths and weaknesses. 
See: 
http://www-brs.ub.ruhr-uni-bochum.de/netahtml/HSS/Diss/MeyerChristopher/diss.pdf
https://arxiv.org/pdf/1902.02531.pdf

scenario_purpose: The European Interoperability Framework(EIF) provides guidance to public administrations on how to improve governance of their interoperability activities, establish cross-organisational relationships, streamline processes supporting end-to-end digital services, and ensure that existing and new legislation do not compromise interoperability efforts.This CAMSS Scenario allows to assess the compliance of interoperability specifications with the EIF. The objective of the obtained assessment is to determine the suitability of the assessed interoperability specification for the delivery of interoperable European public services.
criterion_description: The standard or specification can be mapped to the EIRA.
statement:
TLS 1.2 is already associated to EIRA ABBs in the European Library Of Specifications (ELIS). More specifically, TLS 1.2 can define the interoperability aspects of the "Network",  "Networking Service", "Private Network" and "Public Network" ABBs of the EIRA Technical View.

See: 
https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/solution/elis/distribution/eliscataloguev100betaxlsx

criterion_description: Mechanisms to assess conformity of the implementations of the standard or specification (e.g. conformity tests, certifications) are available for free.
statement:
No tools assessing the conformity of implementations with the specification have been found coming from the IETF. However, there are existing tools available on open source to check the conformity and performance of TLS including version being assessed TLS 1.2. 

See: 
https://github.com/drwetter/testssl.sh

criterion_description: The standard or specification is recommended by a EU Member State.
statement:
7 Member States are recommending TLS 1.2 in their ICT Catalogues.

See: 
https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/collection/common-assessment-method-standards-and-specifications-camss/camss-list-standards

scenario_purpose: The European Interoperability Framework(EIF) provides guidance to public administrations on how to improve governance of their interoperability activities, establish cross-organisational relationships, streamline processes supporting end-to-end digital services, and ensure that existing and new legislation do not compromise interoperability efforts.This CAMSS Scenario allows to assess the compliance of interoperability specifications with the EIF. The objective of the obtained assessment is to determine the suitability of the assessed interoperability specification for the delivery of interoperable European public services.
criterion_description: The standard or specification has been selected for its use in a EU cross-border project or initiative after agreed identification and assessment.
statement:
TLS 1.2 has been widely adopted by public administrations in order to secure the communications over Internet. 
An example of its use in a cross-border project is the Union Registry from the European Commission "Climate Action, Energy for a changing World". The initiative restricted its use to a web browsers supporting TLS 1.2. 
See: 
https://unionregistry.ec.europa.eu/euregistry/EU/index.xhtml

statement:
7 Member States are recommending TLS 1.2 in their ICT Catalogues. 

See CAMSS List of Standards:
https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/collection/common-assessment-method-standards-and-specifications-camss/camss-list-standards

scenario_purpose: The European Interoperability Framework(EIF) provides guidance to public administrations on how to improve governance of their interoperability activities, establish cross-organisational relationships, streamline processes supporting end-to-end digital services, and ensure that existing and new legislation do not compromise interoperability efforts.This CAMSS Scenario allows to assess the compliance of interoperability specifications with the EIF. The objective of the obtained assessment is to determine the suitability of the assessed interoperability specification for the delivery of interoperable European public services.
criterion_description: The standard or specification is included in a catalogue of standards at EU level.
statement:
The rules on European standardisation allow the European Commission to identify information and communication technology (ICT) technical specifications - that are not national, European or international standards - to be eligible for referencing in public procurement. This allows public authorities to make use of the full range of specifications when buying IT hardware, software and services, allowing for more competition in the field and reducing the risk of lock-in to proprietary systems.

After being evaluated compliant with the regulation on standardisation 1025/2012, TLS 1.2 has been identified by Commission Implementing Decision and included in the European list of ICT Standards for e-procurement.

See: 
https://ec.europa.eu/growth/industry/policy/ict-standardisation/ict-technical-specifications_en

scenario_purpose: The European Interoperability Framework(EIF) provides guidance to public administrations on how to improve governance of their interoperability activities, establish cross-organisational relationships, streamline processes supporting end-to-end digital services, and ensure that existing and new legislation do not compromise interoperability efforts.This CAMSS Scenario allows to assess the compliance of interoperability specifications with the EIF. The objective of the obtained assessment is to determine the suitability of the assessed interoperability specification for the delivery of interoperable European public services.
criterion_description: The standard or specification is included in an interoperability agreement established between organisations involved in European public service provision.
statement:
The rules on European standardisation allow the European Commission to identify information and communication technology (ICT) technical specifications - that are not national, European or international standards - to be eligible for referencing in public procurement. This allows public authorities to make use of the full range of specifications when buying IT hardware, software and services, allowing for more competition in the field and reducing the risk of lock-in to proprietary systems.

After being evaluated compliant with the regulation on standardisation 1025/2012, TLS 1.2 has been identified by Commission Implementing Decision. During the evaluation process, all the Member States are invited to share their doubts. The positive evaluation of TLS 1.2 and its identification is considered an interoperability agreement.

See: 
https://ec.europa.eu/growth/industry/policy/ict-standardisation/ict-technical-specifications_en

scenario_purpose: The European Interoperability Framework(EIF) provides guidance to public administrations on how to improve governance of their interoperability activities, establish cross-organisational relationships, streamline processes supporting end-to-end digital services, and ensure that existing and new legislation do not compromise interoperability efforts.This CAMSS Scenario allows to assess the compliance of interoperability specifications with the EIF. The objective of the obtained assessment is to determine the suitability of the assessed interoperability specification for the delivery of interoperable European public services.
criterion_description: The standard or specification is compliant with a European standardisation regulation (e.g. regulation 1025/2012 on European standardisation).
statement:
The rules on European standardisation allow the European Commission to identify information and communication technology (ICT) technical specifications - that are not national, European or international standards - to be eligible for referencing in public procurement. This allows public authorities to make use of the full range of specifications when buying IT hardware, software and services, allowing for more competition in the field and reducing the risk of lock-in to proprietary systems.

After being evaluated compliant with the regulation on standardisation 1025/2012, TLS 1.2 has been identified by Commission Implementing Decision.

See: 
https://ec.europa.eu/growth/industry/policy/ict-standardisation/ict-technical-specifications_en
